newsitem.title: BELGIUM: EU, Japan agree on '97 Japanese car exports.
newsitem.headline: EU, Japan agree on '97 Japanese car exports.

text.p: The European Union and Japan have agreed that Tokyo can ship 1,092,000 cars to the EU in 1997, virtually unchanged from last year's limit, the European Commission said on Wednesday.
The figure was agreed during regular consultations on a six-year-old agreement between the two sides to monitor Japanese car exports to the EU.
The two sides also agreed specific import limits for Britain, France, Italy, Portugal and Spain which previously had national import restrictions on Japanese cars.
The EU agreed in 1991 to open up its market to Japanese cars progressively and to end restrictions completely at the end of 1999.
The figures negotiated each year take into account market developments and the preceding year's figures.
In the last two years Japan has not filled the whole quota. Last year, only 808,000 units were exported to the EU, about 75 percent of the agreed limit of 1,093,000.
"Over the last two years the Japanese have not managed to import and sell as many cars as agreed," Commission spokesman Jochen Kubosch told reporters.
But he stressed that the present system with negotiations about car imports would be in force until the end of 1999 and that the market situation could change in that time.
"One cannot preclude the fact that the market situation could change over the next two years," he said.
The European Commission and the Japanese government will hold further talks in the autumn to update the figures in the light of market developments.
These are the export limits for the five countries with specific limits:
